treat.Creating a catwalk experience like no other, award-winning theatre makers Two Destination Language are presenting their most ambitious project yet.Examining the ever blurring cultural lines between how we look and how we see each other, Fault Lines will bring five strong, brave and erse femme performers together to share one stage, with each audience member choosing their own accompanying narrative.Itrsquos a cast that is erse in background, erse in colour, and erse in ability.Audiences will meet Damyana Radeva, whose story was told so powerfully in Two Destination Languagersquos debut show Near Gone Caroline Ryan, performer and award-winning British Sign Language interpreter, who will be speaking her own script and her own dialogue throughout, privileging BSL and D deaf audience members Cindy Awor, a young actor who describes herself as ldquoa Scot from Uganda, Welly OrsquoBrien, a disabled dancer who performs without a prosthetic leg Hannah Yahya Hassan, an autistic Scottish-Bahraini performer and Rachel Glower, who performs in the show as well as stage manages, driving the cast on and ensuring they ride the catwalk.The audience will experience the show as a kind of historical, political, musical silent disco.Using the Listen Everywhere app, every audience member will be able to navigate between six distinct channels at their own pace.This is the only show where you can flick between a playlist of guilty pleasures, a history of the domination of the English language, and personal narratives of otherness and belonging, each of these and more illuminating the flowing garments, breaking stilettos and killer looks sashaying down the runway.This is a show that foregrounds the beauty in our dferences.Combining playfulness, movement and text, Fault Lines invites audiences to question their own assumptions in this powerful play of identity, equality and inequality in this time of tectonic shts.Fault Lines takes over the Victoria hall on Tuesday, February  from pm.

title: magnificent-cape-clouds-showcased-marchmont-textiles-celebration
story: MARCHMONT House is bringing together international speakers for a special event exploring the past, present and future of arts  crafts textiles.And the Cape of Clouds ndash covered with embroidered messages from women around the world ndash will be at the heart of the special event.The celebration, which features many experts in their field, takes place on Saturday, February .It brings together a remarkable mix of speakers from art experts and curators to contemporary artists and makers - alongside a social enterprise founder who trains women in textile use and design.The accompanying display of work will feature not only Louise Gardinerrsquos cape but an arts  crafts kimono, mixing modern and upcycled th-century material, created by Dumfries and Galloway textile designer Morag McPherson.There will be two contemporary quilts by the internationally renowned designer and maker Pauline Burbidge whose work is in major museum and gallery collections worldwide.The display also includes pieces by Naomi Robertson, master weaver at Dovecot in Edinburgh and antique textiles by Ernest Gimson and now belonging to Barley Roscoe.Marchmont House director Hugo Burgersquos drive to help nurture a new arts  crafts movement, promoting hand-crafted work, a sense of community and an appreciation of nature.He said: ldquoThe original arts  crafts movement embodied a purpose that could not be more important for today - celebrating nature, craftsmanship, community and a sense of purpose."Arts  crafts textiles are at the centre of this crucible of interests, replete with hidden stories, inspiration and raw beauty."It couldnrsquot be more timely to e into this field, seeking a new sense of purpose in craftsmanship.These ideas are deeply embedded in the work of speakers such as the contemporary embroiderer Louise Gardiner, from Bristol, whose Cape of Clouds will be displayed in public for the first time.Louise invited women from around the world to stitch ldquostory clouds reflecting their hopes and dreams for a peaceful world of equality and love.Contributions have come in from as far away as Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Hong Kong.She said: ldquoI was overwhelmed by the response, with clouds arriving by post from places far afield and often accompanied by poems, moving letters and photographs.ldquoThe project resonated with so many women and became a collective voice from an international community of women exploring a traditional craft and connecting with each other with hopes for peace and equality. Evenyou canrsquot see your fellow stitchers, yoursquore connected by an invisible thread.Another speaker, Hazel Smith , hopes to include the cape in a graduation ceremony for women who have attended textiles courses run by her organisation ReTweed.The organisation trains women facing barriers in their lives and careers, teaching them new skills they can use to find jobs, set up their own businesses or enjoy as a hobby.She told us: ldquoRe-Tweed is founded on a philosophy very much aligned to the arts  crafts movement. It brings people together into a community of makers, through an arts and crafts industry, giving them a sense of self-esteem and achievement and creating new opportunities for them."It has been the catalyst for  women setting up their own businesses and has helped  to secure jobs ndash contributing to efforts to revive the great tradition of fashion and textiles in the Borders.Re-Tweed members are also contributed to the Great Tapestry of Scotland whose designer, Paul Crummy, is also delivering a talk at the event.The event is sponsored by Edinburgh fine art auctioneers Lyon  Turnbull.Tickets are available from Eventbrite.

title: a7-re-opens-early-following-weekend-closure
story: THE A re-opened yesterday ahead of schedule following a weekend of works just south of Selkirk.Motorists and bus passengers faced y ersions and delays with the closure on Friday evening to allow for the laying of water pipes.Despite the works being scheduled to last until Monday morningat am, the road re-opened to traffic yesterday afternoon.Scott Fraser, regional communities manager at Scottish Water, said: ldquoWe apologise for any disruption this temporary road closure and use of traffic lights caused."

title: history-made-generation-game-arrives-galashiels-burns-club
story: A LITTLE bit of Burns history was made on Friday evening.After more than  years of authorities and performers providing their worldly-wise interpretations and versions of the Bardrsquos poems and songs for the Galashiels Burns Club annual gathering, the verbatim responsibility was partly passed to the younger generation for .In front of a packed Volunteer Hall, -year-old Poppy Lunn and -year-old Oisin Beard took to the stage to deliver confident, entertaining and word-perfect recitals.For Poppy, it would seem, the Bard is in her blood.Following her exquisite Address to the Haggis, the Glendinning Primary pupil explained: ldquoMr grand-dadand unclewere both presidents of the Galashiels Burns Club, and my dadand lots of other family members were in the audience tonight.ldquoI loved doing it.ldquoMy grand-dadrsquos no longer here so I was doing it for him tonight.Both Poppy and Oisin triumphed at last yearrsquos schoolsrsquo Burns competitions in the town.Galashiels Academy first-year pupil Oisin ended up becoming the Borders champion and even appeared at the World Championships in Dumfries.In front of mum-and-dad, Nathan and Olivia, as well as around  guests, he performed an animated and hugely enjoyable To a Louse.He told us: ldquoWhen I did Burns at primary school I really enjoyed it, although I was a little nervous tonight.ldquoIt was a great experience and one I wonrsquot forget.Both young performers were presented with unique, minted Galashiels Burns Club coins from chairman Alastair Christie.Mr Christie, who hopes the generation game will continue in years to come, said: ldquoI think the applause both received says it all.ldquoThey were both terric ndash well done to Poppy and Oisin for making history.Galashiels Burns Club has gained a reputation over the past century or so for its fine suppers, thought-provoking speakers and hugely enjoyable entertainers.While the youthful involvement was undoubtedly a welcome addition, the rest of the proud programme remained firmly intact.As was fitting of such decades of service to the club, David Sanderson and Grant Lees were both honoured with Le Memberships.A humorous and well-read top table also provided plenty reflection, reasoning and revelry.And the entertainers, as is always the case, stepped up to the mark with toe-tapping tunes, songs aplenty, and the necessary epic poems.After a delicious supper, the task of serving up the Immortal Memory of Robert Burns, was given to Ian Landles.The retired history teacher wears his Hawick heart on the sleeve of his jumper, which was undoubtedly made in a Hawick mill.The author, poet and songwriter was quick to remind the gathering of where hersquos from.Ian said: ldquoWhat a great honour it is ndash for you to have a man frae Hawick here tonight.ldquoIt was a privilege to travel along the A ndash a road worthy of any third-world country. One day Irsquoll maybe able to come by train.Landlesrsquo knowledge of Burns must run his authority on everything Hawick fairly close.During a humorous toast, he contextualised the works we know so well to the time of post-Enlightenment curiosity and unrest when they were written.The Bard lived in years of great social and cultural change through industrialisation, urbanisation and revolution.Burns the rebel, Burns the conservationist and Burns the national treasure were all brought to le.Ian concluded: ldquoHis poetry is as relevant as much to the situation wersquore in today.ldquoBurns became the poet for every generation that has followed him.Teviothead farmer John Tullie also made the journey along the A to provide hugely enjoyable recitals of Tam orsquo Shanter and Holy Williersquos Prayer.The veteran athletics champion was wildly animated yet masterful with the poems.He said: ldquoItrsquos an honour for a poor peasant frae Teviothead to be here in Galashiels.Tom Tinlinrsquos joke book must be bulging as much as his waistline.The agricultural rep from Kelso enjoyed some hilarious self-deprecation, particularly about weight issues, before an enlightening discussion about the women in Burnsrsquo le.Having appeared on stage with the Kelso amateur dramatic group  times, itrsquos no surprise Tom knew how to play his audience with his toast to The Lassies.Providing the musical interludes was the powerful singing from Sam Cleland, with among others Parcel orsquo Rogues and the Star of Rabbie Burns, Chris Achenbachrsquos highly skilful piano playing, Dave Darlingrsquos toe-tapping violin, and the stirring pipes of Bruce Hastie.Armed with his customary Stetson, guitar and mid-Atlantic twang, the ever-popular George Inglis even brought some Americana to proceedings.African-born chiropractor Donald Francis was tasked with honouring the Bard and Scotland with Lands Orsquo Cakes, Caledonia.The former Army captain, who saw active service in the Falklands, the former Yugoslavia and Iraq, moved to Selkirk more than a decade ago.And there was plenty of squaddie humour amidst the genuine affection for his adopted homeland.Donald, who was the Ex-Servicemenrsquos Standard Bearer during a recent Selkirk Common Riding, said: ldquoThe Borders is the best kept secret in the whole of these lands.ldquoWhen I first moved here I was often going to stop and take photographs and I had to remind myself, I live here.ldquoI have visited  countries and have lived in six of them ndash nowhere compares to here.ldquoMy daily treat is to live somewhere so lovely.Gareth Scott provided the fitting vote of thanks to bring a fitting and historic tribute to Robert Burns to a close.

title: lamont-backs-carlaw-tory-leadership-race
story: BORDERS MP, John Lamont, has given his support to Jackson Carlaw MSP, who is standing to be the leader of the Scottish Conservative  Unionist Party.Jackson is currently the interim leader of the party who took over when Ruth Davidson stood down last year. He also stood in for Ruth whilst she was on maternity leave. Jackson has been an MSP since .John joins local MSP, Rachael Hamilton, in supporting Jackson.Mr Carlaw visited the Borders last week to speak to Scottish Conservative activists and ask for their support in the upcoming election.He has committed to a review of existing Scottish Conservative policies and subjecting them to rigorous tests to determinethey should continue to be in the partyrsquos offering to Scotland.Scottish Conservative party members will shortly begin voting in the leadership election with the result being announced on  February.Commenting John Lamont MP said: ldquoI have known Jackson for a very long time. Jackson and I were both elected to the Scottish Parliament at the same time back in  so I know that he has the ability to challenge Nicola Sturgeon and her SNP Government ahead of the Scottish elections in .ldquoHe also has the experience of being our leader, doing so whilst Ruth Davidson was on maternity leave and since she stepped down as leader. Week in, week out we have all seen how well he can hold Nicola Sturgeon to account in Holyrood.ldquoScotland has important elections in  ndash just  months away. We will have a choice between Nicola Sturgeonrsquos SNP which will continue their obsession with independence or we can elect an alternative government which will focus on our NHS, schools and other critical public services which the SNP have neglected so badly. I believe that Jackson is the best person to bring about the change that Scotland desperately needs.

title: douglas-appointed-enterprise-manager-gala
story: THE man tasked with revitalising Galashiels town centre has been unveiled as Douglas Watt.The -year-old, who is from the town, will spend the next  months leading regeneration activities in a bid to reverse the current decline.As well as providing training for local businesses, developing events and attractions, and promotional work, Douglas will also attempt to make the town more welcoming with the installation of street art and murals.Douglas told us: ldquoAfter spending the last  years working in the town, I am excited by the opportunity presented by the role, for both myself and the town."Everyone is aware of the challenges faced by high streets throughout the UK, and Galashiels is no dferent."I am happy to be involved with those who are taking a proactive approach to dealing with these challenges, and look forward to making a positive dference.As well as unveiling Douglas as the community enterprise manager, Energise Galashiels also revealed a new brand to help market the town.Included in the new promotional material is a striking new logo and a strapline.And it is hoped that businesses, community groups and charities will use the brand, and become ambassadors for Galashiels.Debbie Paterson from Energise Galashiels explained: ldquoThe branding project was just as much about the journey as the result."We involved a erse cross-section of the community to help pull together ideas, opinions and emotions."The key theme that came through was lsquoheartrsquo, which is embedded in the brand logo as well as the strapline."We hope that the people, community groups and businesses of Galashiels use the brand as a stamp of pride and positivity.Mr Watt is the first of four enterprise managers to be appointed across the Borders.Councillor Mark Rowley, spokesman for business, said: ldquoIt is fantastic that Galashiels has its community enterprise manager in post.ldquoThe post is a  month pilot being supported by the South of Scotland Economic Partnership, and is one of four across the Borders with the others to be appointed in Eyemouth, Jedburgh and Hawick, which have all been identied as priority regeneration towns.ldquoThe aim of these posts is to work with local communities to support new and developing projects which will have a positive economic impact.ldquoThe new brand for Galashiels is another positive step forward which the council has supported as part of a range of regeneration projects ndash including the Great Tapestry of Scotland visitor centre - which we expect will revitalise the town.

title: graham-douglas---appreciation
story: Graham Douglas - an appreciationIt was the end of an era both for the Border Union Agricultural Societyand fencing contractors, Wm. Douglas and Sons of Lilliesleaf, on Christmas Eve when Graham Douglas died .The Douglas family business was started at the end of the First World War by William Douglas, who had three sons Willie, Dan and Jimmy, who on leaving school in turn all joined the family business. Through time Willie and Jimmy both retired early from the firm through ill health and when Dan retired in  the business was taken over by Williersquos son, William , and long time colleague, Bill Reid . Graham became the fourth generation Williamto work in the business after leaving school and in  took over the business when his father, Bill, retired.The Douglas family took over the building of the annual Border Union Show and Kelso Ram Sales in  and the Championship Dog Show since the first Show in , completing  years for the former and  years for the latter respectively in .It is interesting to note they succeeded Messrs. Bulman, builders Kelso who had been involved with BUAS since . To have had only two main Contractors in over  years is indicative of their skills and loyalties.Graham was very clever at school with a good practical brain and I heard from his le long friend, Andy Shortreed, that he was an expert at, among other things, technical drawing and would make all manner of things out of wood and other material.He was encouraged to study and utilise these skills while at High School in Hawick but Graham was stubborn! All he wanted to do was leave school and join his father, Bill, and be a fencer, which he duly did in .Countless number of farms and estates throughout the Borders have benefited from Grahamrsquos skill, as have the three core events at BUAS. His younger brother, Neil, was in partnership with Graham for a number of years before ing to utilising his skills with heavy plant machinery.I cannot have more regard and respect for Bill and Graham and how they nurtured me when I joined BUAS as Secretary in . I listened and I learnt from them all the ins and outs of both the Showground and preparing these massive annual Events and bringing them together in such a professional manner and with an uncanny calmness that sometimes was frustrating but one knew that come the day the target was reached. The Ram Sales have evolved over the last  years with many changes and updates and it was a pleasure working with someone who was always conscious of the huge responsibility he had to the many thousands of people, whose livelihoods were often very dependant on a good Ram Sales or a good Show, whether buying, selling, exhibiting, a Trade Stand, providing a service or a member of the public.Grahamrsquos other passion in le was his racing pigeons, which he has bred and raced for over  years - and for the last  with his friend and near neighbour in Lilliesleaf, Bob Spearman. They had many years of great fun and indeed numerous successes with their birds and it was always a great pleasure and exciting for those at the Showground when in the spring Graham would very often bring a crate of young birds when he came to work and released them as part of their early training. A master breeder even he did not understand how the young birds knew which direction was home!He had a great eye and would spend many long evenings just watching the birds to learn which would be potential race winners and which to keep as breeding stock. They had their fair share of success in UK races, whether from Edinburgh or the south coast of England but their biggest success was when one of their favourites ndash Bonnie Lad ndash finished th out , birds released from the South of France. No-one does fathom how these incredible birds find their way home and I believe these two wise owls were also baffled but enjoyed the discussion and banter over a pint or two in the local pub. Thankfully Bob Spearman is carrying on with the ldquoLilliesleaf Legends pigeon flock.Grahamrsquos greatest assets were that he was honest, thorough and reliable with great attention to detail in anything and all in which he was involved. He is survived by his we, Anne, two daughters, mother, his two brothers and his two sisters.Irreplaceable but not forgotten in Lilliesleaf, Kelso and the Borders, William Graham Douglas, his father Bill, his grandfather, Willie, and his great grandfather, William.Ron Wilson

title: alleged-stalker-remanded-custody
story: A -year-old man has been remanded in custody at Jedburgh Sherf Court after being accused of stalking a former partner.Vincent Cardle - who gave an address in Roxburghshire - made no plea during a private hearing and the case was continued for further examination.Bail was refused and he was remanded in custody and is due to appear in court again later this week.

title: douglas-crawford-announced-2020s-melrosian-elect
story: LEADING as this years Melrosian-elect,is -year-old Douglas Crawford.Douglas, who is currently studying a Masters degree in Performance Psychology at the University of Edinburgh, was revealed as the new Melrosian at the annual Ex-Melrosian Burns Supper last weekend.Douglas told us: "Im really excited, Im looking forward to the summer now."It was a really good night, the speakers were fantastic, last years Melrosian, Ben, spoke well."I had a lot of family there so it was really special to be announced."Douglas will join other members of his family, including his father, who have taken up the role of Melrosian in the past, which he said makes the honour "even more special."He added: "I and my family are so grateful for this opportunity."Im just looking forward to the festivities getting underway."The Corn Exchange played host to the sell-out evening on Saturday, January , celebrating the Bards birthday where guests were entertained by an outstanding lineup of speakers and entertainers.Stephen Amos gave the Immortal Memory and the Toast to the Lassies was made by Melrosian , Ben Magowan, which was matched by an excellent reply from Rev. Rosie Frew.The Address to the Haggis was undertaken by Douglass father, Michael Crawford, and Annabel Crawford performed the Tam o Shanter.A new approach was taken to the toast and reply to Town and Trade at this years supper, as Christopher Bell and Gary Flannigan performed a Melrose version of Mastermind and News at .The vote of thanks was proposed by retiring Left Hand Man, Russell Mackay.This years week-long Melrose Festival will take place between Sunday, June  and Saturday, June .The Rideout will be on June , and the Crowning of the Festival Queen will be on June .

title: week-long-february-school-holiday-agreed-council
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council have agreed to implement a week-long holiday for pupils and a four-day-long break for teachers in February.The changes wont come into effect however, until the school year beginning .As well as the February break, the Council agreed the dates for school in-service days at a meeting of the Executive on Tuesday, January .The dates were suggested after a public consultation held between September and October last year.The consultation received more than  responses which overwhelmingly supported the addition of the week off in February.The Council decided to give two in-service days after the summer holiday, one after the October break, one in February and another the Tuesday following May bank holiday.These dates will apply to the school years   and  .As previously reported, the Council was considering beginning works to align future in-service dates for Borders schools with those in Edinburgh, Fe, Midlothian and East Lothian.At the meeting on January , the Council agreed to begin discussions regarding the setting of dates from   until  .Councillor Carol Hamilton, SBCrsquos Executive Member for Children and Young People, said: ldquoWe would like to thank everyone who took part in the consultation as we were keen to have as representative a view of local opinion as possible.ldquoWe will now progress discussions with neighbouring local authorities to scope out how practical and effective it will be for us to align in-service days and holidays with each other, and what benefits this might bring.The holiday and in-service dates beginning from   to   available on the Councilrsquos website at, www.scotborders.gov.uk schoolholidays

title: search-rehome-rare-artefacts-following-community-eviction-earlston
story: COMMUNITY leaders in Earlston are busy searching for new homes for historical documents and artefacts after a Borders estate has claimed back its building.The historic Reading Room were built in the town during the mid-th century to encourage education.A Trust was responsible for the running of the popular Market Square building for more than a century.Although the three-storey building hasnt been used as a private subscription library since the s, it had remained as a meeting room and storage area for historic books and documents, as well as the towns vast array of Christmas lights.Attempts have been made in recent years to form a Trust to bring the Reading Room back to their former glory.And surveys have been carried out to establish the viability of a community facility.But a shock email from legal representatives of Mellerstain Estate towards the end of last year has ended the plans.Solicitors acting on behalf of the Earl of Haddington, owner of Mellerstain, indicated that the estate had ownership of the building - and they wanted it back.The lawyers were also investigating the ownership of books within the rooms.Sheila Gibb, chair of Earlston Community Council, told us: "The Community Council and Scottish Borders Council have been working together to establish the position regarding the Reading Room."Its a very complex legal situation as well as a building that is in a poor state of disrepair."At the moment Scottish Borders Council are supporting us as we look to relocate the books and artefacts held in the building."The Christmas Lights Committee are doing the same for their equipment and displays."A meeting was first held to gauge support for the creation of a Reading Room in .It was reported at the time, Major Baillie of Mellerstain offered an initial donation of  books for the library.A committee was formed with Major Baillie as President, with a librarian appointed as manager.Many prominent members of the Earlston community, including the headmaster, minister and surgeon, served on the committee.Both the Reading Room and the Recreation Room were open every day, between the hours of am and pm, except Sundays and New Years Day.A wide selection of books were gted and loaned to the Reading Room during the years which followed.By  the facility had amassed around  volumes with a membership of  local people.A billiards table was also placed in the Recreation Room.During a celebration to mark the centenary of the opening on June ,  it was noted that among the valuable possessions being held in the Reading Room were a lock of Sir Walter Scotts hair as well as his autograph.But the opening of a public library in the s as well as the deaths of the Trustees over the following decade or so, led to a gradual decline in both the popularity and condition of the building.,params: .pushIt is thought the Reading Room Trust stopped operating in the s.In recent years attempts have been made to restore the building and bring it back into community use.A feasibility study was carried out by Scottish Borders Council last year which estimated that around pound, would be required to complete any community restoration project.But the recent correspondence by Mellerstain Estate over ownership has put a spanner in the works.Local councillor David Parker believes it is unlikely the community will be able to oppose the claims.He said: "The community has had an aspiration to do something with the Reading Rooms, and in  I was handed some information about the historical operation."That information suggested that Mellerstain Estate had always had a claim on the building but the Reading Room had been operated under a Trust model, with the Trust basically becoming extinct in the late s."If the community wanted to use the Reading Room again, it would need to try to reactivate the Trust and get permission to do that from the Sherf Court and then find new Trustees."However, the building is in a poor state of internal repair, it requires quite a lot of investment to bring it back into le."

title: consultation-doesnt-convince-council-replace-dated-cctv
story: COUNCIL bosses want to run down the clock on the regionrsquos crumbling CCTV network.Although officers donrsquot believe immediate decommissioning of the arearsquos  cameras should be undertaken, they are recommending that members of the local authority only approve enough cash to continue minimal ad-hoc maintenance.And once the dated systems finally falter, they should be removed.Currently one-in-four of the cameras around Borders town centres arenrsquot working with many more expected to go offline in the next couple of years.The planned eventual black-out of monitoring in eight town centres ndash Duns, Eyemouth, Galashiels, Hawick, Kelso, Melrose, Peebles and Selkirk ndash follows a region-wide consultation.Although the majority of the  respondents believed that CCTV was effective in fighting crime and provided a safer environment, Scottish Borders Council isnrsquot willing to spend the estimated pound, on a replacement system.SBC team leader Alex Young said: ldquoThe councilrsquos current position with regard to CCTV provision is not to install new CCTV equipment or replace le-expired systems but to continue to maintain the current asset within the existing revenue budget until they are beyond economic repair.Although the cameras are used to provide evidence following crimes, Police Scotland has continually refused to help fund the upkeep or replacement of the system.And, with the local authority already footing a pound, bill for two Police Community Action Teams, many councillors believe the Police should be paying their way.Police Scotland didnrsquot provide any information regarding the use of CCTV during the recent local authority consultation.Mr Young added: ldquoWhile the Police are supportive of continuing to provide a CCTV provision within the local communities, Police Scotland are not in a position to contribute to the funding of public space CCTV in the Borders, either in terms of the initial capital investment or on-going revenue costs.ldquoOfficers have unfortunately been unable to determine, or obtain, any substantive data or statistical information that demonstrates the frequency at which CCTV footage is accessed in any given community, the basis on which this footage might be used to support any legal action or community safety initiative or indeed its use in any successful prosecution.ldquoPolice Scotland have been requested to provide a formal statement but unfortunately to date have been unable to do so.Councillors are being recommended to continue maintaining the current system until it no longer works when they meet on Thursday.

title: gala-bookies-defies-odds-become-best-uk
story: A SMALL betting office in Galashiels has upset the odds by becoming the the top shop in Britain.Hundreds of William Hill branches across the UK were in contention for the prize.But co-managers Anthony Lenton and Malcolm Howden, along with cashiers Jamie, Pamela and Jack, came with a late run down the outside to get the nod from judges.Not only was the Market Street bookies short-listed for the Top of the Shops category, but they were also in the shake-up for the Give a Damn award.Anthony admits his team were over the moon when the announcement was made last week during a glitzy ceremony in Cheshire.He said: "There was a big party afterwards."There are around  William Hill shops in the UK yet we are now officially the best."Theres a senior manager who writes reports up on the shops each month and they also compile feedback from customers."Wed like to thank all of our customers who make sure the shop is a friendly and enjoyable place to be."As well as the Top of the Shops trophy, the staff each pocketed pound.And they are also expecting a delivery of goodies to help reward their loyal customers over the coming weeks.Although the Galashiels branch was named in the last four of the Give a Damn category, it was pipped at the post.Over the past year, the branch has raised more than pound for good causes, including the Margaret Kerr Unit, Alzheimers Scotland and Stand Up to Cancer.They also collect items to send to Borders Pet Rescue.Anthony added: "We were the only category winner from Scotland."Wersquove managed to put our small town on the map within our company - loads of people within William Hill are now asking us where is Galashiels "

title: castle-needs-volunteers-help-extend-summer-hours
story: A SCOTTISH Borders heritage site needs volunteers as it looks to open its doors seven days a week.Thirlestane Castle, Lauder, which is one of the oldest inhabited castles in Scotland, hopes to stay open seven days a week during the summer season so visitors have more opportunities to visit the th century castle.But, to do this, the castle is in need of more volunteers to help increase the number of room stewards and guides available on site.The Friends of Thirlestane guide guests around the building, highlighting some of the unique collections in its ownership, including family portraits and the upcoming summer exhibition, School Room Toy Museum, which will display a large collection of Edwardian, Victorian and Georgian toys.The Castle Trust is asking anyone with time to spare, even just a half day, to get in touch and join their volunteer team.And its not just stewards and guides who are needed, shop staff and greeters are also an important role for a Thirlestane volunteer.An interest in history is necessary either as the castle want volunteers who can make every guests visit a great experience.People interested in becoming a volunteer get shown around the castle and are introduced to the current Friends of Thirlestane team.Edward Maitland-Carew, owner of Thirlestane, said: ""We are so indebted to lsquoThe Friends of Thirlestanersquo who do an amazing job welcoming our visitors and sharing this fabulous castlersquos stories with them."Without this wonderful group of people we would not be able to open to the public every summer."Please do consider joining the team and coming along to our Open Morning to see how you can help protect this magnicent building for future generations."An Open Morning for prospective volunteers will be held on Thursday, March .For more information, or to register your interest in the Open Morning, visit www.thirlestanecastle, or email enquiries@thirlestanecastleOr you can call the castle on  .

title: peebles-students-given-final-go-ahead-high-school-return
story: STUDENTS from Peebles High School have been given the final confirmation that they will be ing to the fire-hit school next week.After the blaze that caused signicant damage to the school on Thursday, November , S-S students will start their classes in the High School on Monday, February , whereas students from S-S will begin on Tuesday, February .S-S students are asked, however, to spend Monday completing work provided through the Show My Homework app and Glow.But students with complex needs, who joined the specialist facility at Galashiels Academy on December , will remain there whilst plans to accommodate their needs are developed at the Peebles site.Chief Executive of Scottish Borders Council, Tracey Logan, said: ldquoPhasing theof pupils enables us to manage the preparations effectively."One of the most challenging elements is moving from the seven temporary S-S teaching sites in Peebles from the end of the school day on Friday  January, hence the additional day to complete this.ldquoAn enormous amount of work has been needed to get us to the position of having all year groups back together in one location ndash something parents have consistently told us was very important to them."To be in a position to do this so quickly is testament to the efforts of all concerned, and the support provided to us by a wide range of partners.ldquoWe do still have work to complete on site, and additional classroom and changing room space will also be opened up in modular buildings later in February, but we are now confident that theof pupils can take place.As studentsto the school, Scottish Borders Council has also announced its Inspire Learning programme will be rolled out.Ms Logan added: ldquoIn preparing for the reoccupation of the school we have been able to install the infrastructure to facilitate the Inspire Learning rollout and I am delighted that we can start this the first week back at the school.An options appraisal is ongoing to evaluate all options for the future of the school, which will impact discussions with Scottish Government and the Peebles community.This appraisal is estimated to be complete by Easter .

title: innerleithen-football-ground-targeted-vandals
story: FURIOUS football officials in Innerleithen are yet again picking up the pieces following a spate of vandalism.Over the past couple of seasons thugs have regularly targeted the Vale of Leithen ground.As well as spraying graffiti and damaging the dug-outs at Victoria Park, smashed bottles are often found in and around the enclosure area of the Lowland League club.Last week the ground was yet again vandalised with further graffiti sprayed onto the dug-outs and pitch-side fencing being kicked down.Vale chairman Stuart Robertson told us: "Football clubs like ours cant afford this kind of damage."Every time these kids come in here and damage the place we have to spend time and money on repairs."Its a problem that goes back years but weve noticed it happening more regularly over the past couple of seasons."Wed ask anyone who sees people in here when they shouldnt be to call the police - this cant go on."The problems in Innerleithen are similar to those experienced by football officials at Whitestone Park in Peebles.Ahead of match days committee members at Peebles Rovers regularly have to clean up broken bottles and litter from their stand.And there have been several incidents of damage to the dug-outs, pitch-side fencing and clubrooms.Peebles Rovers chairman Mark Bisset told us: ldquoWe are struggling financially and really canrsquot afford to continually repair."We would love to install CCTV but we just canrsquot afford it."I asked the council to put a bin back at the stand as the last one was burned."Anyone who witnesses vandalism at either Victoria Park in Innerleithen or Whitestone Park in Peebles is asked to contact Police Scotland on .

title: 31-year-old-admits-causing-disturbances-galashiels-shops
story: A GALASHIELS man has appeared from custody at Selkirk Sherf Court and admitted being involved in three disturbances.Shane Lawrence, , pleaded guilty to shouting and swearing, refusing to leave the Borders Pharmacy premises in Galashiels on Saturday when requested to do so.Two days later at the Premier Store in Galashiels he was shouting and swearing, uttering threats of violence and acting aggressively.Also on Monday he behaved in a threatening or abusive manner at Galashiels and Hawick Police stations.The court was told there was an alcohol problem in the background of the offending.Sentence was deferred until February  for the production of background reports.

title: call-social-security-controls-thousands-seek-welfare-help-borders
story: A TOTAL of  Crisis Grants and Community Care Grants were issued for hard-up Borderers during the three months of  up to October.The payments cover essentials such as food, heating costs, and household necessities.And they show a  percent increase in demand from the same three-month period of last year.Local MSP Christine Grahame believes the impact from Brexit will see the need for payments from the Scottish Welfare Fund continue to grow.And she is calling for the Scottish government to have full controls over social security.The SNP member for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, told us: "The Scottish Welfare Fund is a vital leline for many people facing poverty or crisis.ldquoBut the fact that so many households in the Borders have been forced to turn to the fund for emergency financial help is extremely concerning.ldquoThe Scottish Government spends millions every year shielding Scots from UK Government welfare cuts."That our devolved Government should have to protect its citizens from the cruelty of the UK state is unacceptable and unsustainable.ldquoAnd with the threat of Brexit still alive ndash the risk is real that tens of thousands more people could be pushed into poverty in Scotland, and left at the mercy of this heartless Tory government.ldquoOnly with full powers over social security can we begin to make Scotland an equal country with a dignied and fair welfare system. Until then, the SNP will continue to do everything in our power to tackle poverty and support low income families.Since its launch in April , the Scottish Welfare Fund has paid out almost pound million to over , households across the country ndash with , households in the Borders receiving help from the Scottish government fund.In total a third of households receiving awards were families with children.

title: council-call-outlaw-sports-pitch-poo-pests
story: BORDERS councillors are pushing for poo pests at sports pitches to face fines and even court.Over the past decade volunteers at clubs across the region have regularly complained about dog mess on their parks.Many officials have to regularly inspect their grounds, armed with a bucket spade, ahead of kick offs.Football, hockey and rugby grounds are all affected by dog mess as are school playing fields and even playparks.Kelso councillor Tom Weatherston led the calls for dog fouling on any sports pitch or play area to become an offence - eventhey clean up afterwards.Councillor Weatherston told us: "The law at present allows dogs to foul anywhere in an open space, provided their owner or walker clears up after them."As a result, you have a situation where sports clubs and others have to clean up dog mess before they can use pitches."This is completely unacceptable and the law needs to be changed.Members of Scottish Borders Council this week backed the motion for anyone allowing their dog to poo on a pitch or playpark to be charged.But for the addition to be added onto the Dog FoulingAct  it will require the consent of Holyrood.Councillor Weatherston added: "The council will now write to the Scottish Government, asking it to amend the law to make it an offence for a person in charge of a dog to allow it to defecate at any time on a sports pitch or childrenrsquos play area."

title: stitch-tour-set-promote-tapestrys-new-home-borders
story: BORDERERS will have their chance to stitch themselves into history this spring.As part of the build-up to the Great Tapestry of Scotland centre opening in Galashiels next year, promoters are going on the road.At ious historic locations around the region, as well as wider Scotland, there will be an opportunity for visitors to stitch part of the Welcome .And everyone who threads part of the  will have their name recorded as a contributor to the Tapestryrsquos visitor centre.The Great Tapestry of Scotlandrsquos pound. million purpose built interactive visitor centre is due to open next April.Centre director Sandy Maxwell-Forbes is already getting excited.She told us: ldquoTelling the peoplersquos story of Scotland and making this story accessible to everyone has always been at the heart of the Great Tapestry of Scotland, so wersquore incredibly excited to be giving those who live in Scotland, and those visitors who love our country so much, an opportunity to stitch their name in Scotlandrsquos history through our new Welcome Panel tour."We would like to thank all the venues and event organisers throughout Scotland who are making this possible."In keeping with the Great Tapestry of Scotlandrsquos ethos, it is vital that as many people as possible have an opportunity to contribute to the ."As part of the tour, wersquore taking the Welcome Panels directly to venues, such care homes, to remove some of the barriers that some iniduals face to accessing such signicant cultural projects."We will add more venues throughout the year.The tour, which will stop at Abbotsford, Floors Castle, Traquair and Marchmont, will give people the chance to work with some of the countryrsquos leading textile artists.When complete, the new Welcome to Scotlandrsquos Story  will be permanently displayed at the entrance to the Great Tapestry of Scotland centre.Catherine Maxwell Stuart from Traquair is hosting the Welcome Panel tour on May  and .She said: ldquoWe are looking forward to the Great Tapestry of Scotland having a permanent home in the Scottish Borders where we hope it will draw visitors from far and wide to appreciate this outstanding cultural achievementldquoOver  years Traquair has witnessed extraordinary events in Scotlandrsquos history, so we know only too well how important it is to hear Scotlandrsquos stories as told by Scotlandrsquos people."With our own strong heritage of textile and embroideries it is wonderful to see these unique traditions being carried on to the st century."We are delighted to be part of the Welcome Panel tour with this wonderful team of textile artists giving residents and visitors to Scotland in  an opportunity to part of this story.Many of the stories told through the Great Tapestry of Scotland, which was completed in , have strong ties to the history, heritage and culture that can be experienced on a visit to Scotland.Building on this and, continuing the Tapestryrsquos ethos to tell the peoplersquos story of Scotland, the new Welcome Panels will tell some of the true stories linked to the visitor centrersquos new home in the Scottish Borders.The  will feature a reiver, a shepherd, a monk, a mill worker and a fisher lass.By the time they are completed, it is hoped that over , dferent people from across Scotland and beyond will have contributed to the stitching.Giles Ingram, chief executive of Abbotsford, will welcome the tour on Saturday, May .He said: ldquoWe are really looking forward to the opening of the Great Tapestry of Scotland."Itrsquos a wonderful new attraction for the Borders that will engage visitors with its depiction of Scottish people, places and events, many of which were very important to Sir Walter Scott and his stories.ldquoAbbotsford is delighted to be a part of the tapestryrsquos story today and to give our visitors an opportunity to make their mark on an important piece of Scottish cultural history.The tour will also visit Glasgow and Aberdeen during the spring.

title: first-cases-coronavirus-confirmed-newcastle
story: TWO people from the same family have tested positive for coronavirus in the UK.And it is believed they are receiving treatment at the Royal Victoria Infirmary in Newcastle.The government confirmed the newsat .am this morning.It is understood the pairwere holidaying in York and were taken to a specialist unit at the RVI in Newcastle when they fell ill.But cases could be confirmed later as a flight from the epicentre of the outbreak, Wuhan is China, lands at RAF Brize Norton in West Oxfordshire.The plane, carrying  British people and  foreign nationals, is due to arriveat .pm.The two cases of the virus are the first to be diagnosed in the UK.In a statement chief medical officer for England, professor Chris Whitty said: "The patients are receiving specialist NHS care, and we are using tried and tested infection control procedures to prevent further spread of the virus."The NHS is extremely well-prepared and used to managing infections and we are already working rapidly to identy any contacts the patients had, to prevent further spread."We have been preparing for UK cases of novel coronavirus and we have robust infection control measures in place to respond immediately."We are continuing to work closely with the World Health Organisation and the international community as the outbreak in China develops to ensure we are ready for all eventualities."

title: credits-roll-scotlands-first-film-town
story: MOVIE lovers will soon be making their way to Hawick - as it bids to become Scotlands first Film Town.The hugely successful Alchemy Film and Arts festival people are extending their calendar to include a year-round programme of big- and small-screen delights.On Friday they unveiled details of events and activities that will underscore the historic centre of the cashmere industryrsquos position as a leading film town.Once Upon A Time in Hawick will celebrate the townrsquos rich history and look to its future through exhibitions and screenings, as well as opportunities for participation and education.Michael Pattison, creative director of Alchemy Film  Arts said: "Once Upon A Time in Hawick places Hawick and its communities at the centre of a major artistic programme, bringing audiences together to exchange stories about the townrsquos past and to share ideas about its future.ldquoThrough the project we will be exploring the identities, industries and stories of Hawick, focusing on the townrsquos unique landscape and history, threading together a celebratory look at the mills - which are central to Hawickrsquos industrial history - and the townrsquos cultures to imagine a future of creativity regeneration and growth.Once Upon A Time in Hawick was launched with a screening of a newly digitally mastered print of From Wool to Wearer, a  film about Peter Scott Knitwear, which is held at the Scottish Borders Archive in Hawickrsquos Heritage Hub.And a centrepiece of Once Upon A Time in Hawick will be the th annual Alchemy Film and Moving Image Festival, from April  to May .Mr Pattison added: "This year sees the th edition of what has become one of Europersquos leading film events and has put Hawick on the international cultural map."We have an exciting programme which will bring filmmakers from across the world to Hawick to explore image-making in relation to place, cultural identity and collective memory.Throughout the year there will be an ongoing programme of participatory events.Experts will work with the communities in and around Hawick on a wide range of projects including film-making and digital skills workshops, the outcomes of which will be shared through exhibitions and screenings.There will be the creation of an archive of films made in Hawick over the last  or so years, and the  Hawick Pictorial, gathering the year in Hawick on film, something which hasnt been done in Hawick in  years and will complement the archive of pictorials from the s, ,  and .An exhibition on Hawickrsquos film industry from the late s to the present day will also be developed.Hawick provost Watson McAteer said: "Alchemy Film  Arts have been an integral part of the le of Hawick for the past  years bringing international and UK visitors to the town and community."This highly creative and original organisation have placed Hawick on the international stage as Scotlandrsquos Film town.ldquoI am delighted that Alchemyrsquos new project for , Once Upon a Time in Hawick, will be exploring the identities, industries and stories of Hawick ultimately bringing our historic and cultural heritage alive through discussion and monthly film screenings. This is a fantastic tribute to Hawick and I would encourage active local support to this wonderful project destined to create something unique and special for our historic townThe first events in Once Upon a Time in Hawick will include a screening on February  of Sons of Heroes,  - a re-enactment of the  Battle of Hornshole which was made in Hawick by Hawick Film and Video Group.During March  to  a project will be held with artists Anna Raczynski and Ed Webb-Ingall,which will feature film-making workshops and screenings of the films made as well as a screening of Raczynskirsquos The Movie Makers.And later in the same month, March  to , there will be screenings of  Hawick Pictorial.Sean Greenhorn from Screen Scotland added: ldquoOnce Upon a Time in Hawick will enable Alchemy Film  Arts to truly work within the fabric of the town, using new equipment to respond to their surroundings, working with local groups to empower them to share their memories and engage with conversations about the future of Hawick.

title: klein-trustees-begin-weaving-legacy-project
story: A YEAR-LONG project to highlight the cultural importance of textile designer Bernat Klein has begun in the Borders.The Serb-colourist moved to Galashiels in the early s to establish a weaving centre.Although highly-regarded, it was the decision by Coco Chanel to use Kleins fabrics for her spring collection of  which gave him greater exposure around the world.Many of the leading design houses of the s, such as Saint Laurent, Balenciaga and Dior, became customers.Klein re-invented himself again in the mid-s and based himself at a purpose-built studio near Selkirk.Employing around  hand-knitters from around the region, he began to produce his own producing clothing collections, as well as upholstery and carpets.The Bernat Klein Foundation was established in  - three years after his death - to promote and develop the designers legacy.After being awarded funding from the Heritage Lottery Fund and the William Grant Foundation, a year-long project began last month.Working with Live Borders, the Borders Textile Towerhouse, and the School of Textiles  Design at Heriot-Watt University, the project will contribute to securing the legacy of Bernat Klein and his unique creative and cultural contribution to the Borders.Trustee Maggie Marr told us: "Through a series of activities, the intergenerational project will engage with people across the Borders to record and promote Kleinrsquos legacy."Work created throughout the project will be showcased in an exhibition to be held at the Borders Textile Towerhouse from November."We would be pleased to hear from people who knew and worked for Bernat Klein."If you would like to share your story or would like more information about the project please get in touch with us at info@bernatkleinfoundation.org we look forward to hearing from you."The opening project event, Interwoven Networks: Bernat Klein and refuges from Nazi Europe, will be held at the Border Towerhouse in Hawick on Sunday, March  from pm to pm.Dr Anna Nyburgand Lisa Masonwill explore the work of Bernat Klein in the context of wider networks of eacutemigreacute designers practicing in post-war Britain.This event will also include a screening of the film Refuge Britain.Tickets can be booked by contacting the Border Textile Towerhouse Museum on -   or at textiletowerhouse@liveborders.org.uk

title: mundell-backs-carlaw-following-hustings
story: BOTH candidates in the Scottish Conservatives leadership election battle went head-to-head in Moffat last weekend.Current interim leader Jackson Carlaw, MSP, who was deputy to former leader Ruth Davidson, and South of Scotland MSP Michelle Ballantyne, from Walkerburn, are bidding for the top job.They addressed nearly  party members at a hustings in the Annandale Hotel on Saturday afternoon before lively question and answer sessions.Mr Carlaw, who represents Eastwood, was in the motor trade for many years before becoming a full-time politician whilst Ms Ballantyne, a former NHS intensive care staff nurse, later worked in health management and has also led a specialist support charity for people facing drugs and alcohol issues.The meeting was chaired by Charles Milroy of Dumfries, former chairman of Dumfries and Galloway Conservative and Unionist Association.All party members in Scotland are eligible to vote with ballot papers being circulated shortly and the new leader is expected to be announced on February .Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale MP David Mundell and his son Dumfriesshire MSP Oliver Mundell helped host the local hustings.Both have publicly endorsed Mr Carlaw as their favoured candidate for the role.David Mundell said: "There was some insightful questioning of both candidates and I was delighted to see such a large turnout on a wet afternoon."

title: bag-n-bin-it-hopes-innerleithen
story: Most of us have been there at one time or another.That boak inducing moment when you step in dog poo.Whatever good mood you may have been in has been completely robbed by the stinking mess that now adorns your shoe.But what do you do about it  Curse, stomp on, and search for a place where you grimace as you try to scrape off the offending faeces.This week Peeblesshire News reporter Hilary Scott was chatting doggie doo with Innerleithen Community Council and discovered what theyrsquove been doing to tackle the poo problem in their town.DOG owners not picking up after their pets are a blight on all settlements up and down the country.However, the community council of Innerleithen decided in January last year they had enough - and embarked on a year-long campaign to eradicate dog fouling.Now, thanks to a successful bid for funding, new bins and bag dispensers have been located throughout the town.ldquoIrsquove always found the notion of dog poo smeared across our streets abhorrent, even as a small child, said community councillor Jackie Couchman.ldquoInnerleithen has a high density of dogs in a relatively small area which magnies the issue.ldquoMost dog owners are responsible and pick up, a sizeable minority do not and, it would seem, will not. I thought it was worth a concerted effort to seewe could make a dference to the state of our streets to benefit everyone. I was prepared to make a personal commitment of time and effort to this cause.The project got off ground last January when Innerleithen community councillors made the decision to try and rid the streets of dog mess.Reflecting on the actions they undertook, Jackie said: ldquoI became involved after Gordon Daly taped plastic bottles to lampposts to dispense free poo bags to those in need."Susan Meikle and I offered to help these from supplies Gordon had procured from the Dogs Trust.The following month, the community council was encouraged by local authority councillors to apply for funding through the Localities Area Bid Fund.ldquoThis concentrated my mind and I took it upon myself to complete the application with offers of help from both a previous applicant and The Bridge, said Jackie.ldquoWe heard our project had been shortlisted to be put to the public vote in time for our May community council meeting.But the timetable for the public voting process was disrupted by other political happenings, and after a tense wait and a flurry of activity to encourage voting, good news was delivered.Jackie added: ldquoWe heard our bid was successful in time for our July meeting."Various conditions had to be met before the funds could be released, including  percent of the amount applied for supplied by us, copies of our constitution and accounts.ldquoHaving won the funding, final details of ordering, delivery, installation and maintenance had to be agreed.Whilst waiting on the new bins to arrive, the community councillors did not rest on their laurels.With the help of SBC leader Shona Haslam, Jackie and Gordon stencilled anti-fouling signs on problem pavements in Innerleithen.Community councillors also mapped out locations for the new bins and Scottish Borders Council agreed to install these and remove or relocate the redundant ones.ldquoOperationally, the local authority agreed to provide the litter bags and to replenish the poo bags with us taking responsibility for funding them, added Jackie.With the bins now in place, the community council is due to meet on Monday to discuss further fundraising initiatives.The townrsquos community council, in particular, the poo-busting trio of Jackie, Gordon and Susan, have worked tirelessly this last year to combat the dog fouling issue in Innerleithen.Nevertheless, inevitable questions remain.Will they no longer witness the flattened deposit bearing the imprint of a shoe, the stressed parent quickly steering their child away from the offending brown mess, or irritated adult repeatedly scraping their foot off a kerb Probably not says Jackie, adding: ldquoWas it worth it  Yes."And in the shorter term it has made a dference."Longer term, my feeling is that it will depend on continuing effort and collective ownership of the problem. People have generally been very supportive although every post on social media has triggered lsquothey wonrsquot ever pick up commentsrsquo."Despite the campaign Jackie says itrsquos unlikely that everyone will become law abiding citizens and pick up after their dog, but says shersquod do it all again in an effort to keep clean the streets and grass verges of the bonnie town she resides in.

title: accuser-cross-examined-emails-weinstein
story: A key accuser has told the rape trial of Harvey Weinstein that she stayed in touch with him after he allegedly raped her to protect her acting career, as the defence sought to paint her as opportunistic manipulator.Asked on cross-examination about warm emails she sent to the movie mogul, the -year-old woman responded: ldquoI wanted him to believe I wasnrsquot a threat.She later added: ldquoI was afraid of his unpredictable anger.Defence lawyer Donna Rotunno also grilled the woman about consensual sex with Weinstein that the accuser claimed only happened after ldquoa long negotiation. Even then, ldquoI wasnrsquot happy to do it, she said.vw,vw,px, px"Donna Rotunno ldquoYou manipulated Mr Weinstein every single time, isnrsquot that correct  Ms Rotunno asked.The woman responded: ldquoI felt there was an aspect to the way I felt I needed to protect myself that had an element of manipulation.Ms Rotunno said: ldquoYou made a choice to have sexual encounters with Harvey Weinstein when you werenrsquot sexually attracted to him. You liked the parties and you liked the power.The lawyer also grilled the accuser about communications that provided him with her new phone number and encouraged him to get in touch.One read: ldquoI got a new number. Just wanted you to have it. Hope you are well and call me anytime, always good to hear your voice, according to court papers.At times during the cross-examination, the woman struggled to recall certain details and at one point asked for a break, saying: ldquoIrsquom getting a little foggy.She ed to the stand after she told jurors last week that Weinstein trapped her in a New York hotel room in March , and angrily ordered her to undress as he loomed over her, and then raped her.A second attack came eight months later at a Los Angeles hotel, where she worked as a hairdresser, after she told Weinstein she was dating an actor, she said.ldquoYou owe me one more time! she said he screamed at her. She said she begged him not to take off her clothes, but he said: ldquoI donrsquot have time for games, and ripped off her trousers before pushing her legs apart and raping her.vw,vw,px, px"Mimi Haleyi The evidence comes at a pivotal moment in the trial of Weinstein, whose downfall energised the MeToo movement. He is charged in New York with the  rape and also sexually assaulting Mimi Haleyi, a former Project Runway production assistant, in .A conviction could put him behind bars for the rest of his le.Weinstein, , has insisted any sexual encounters were consensual..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Accuser cross-examined about emails to Weinstein

title: tottenham-complains-bbc-racism-claims-one-show
story: Tottenham Hotspurrsquos lawyers have written to the BBC accusing producers of unfairly singling out the club for alleged racism during its flagship The One Show programme.And the PA news agency understands the Premier League football club is so far dissatisfied with the publicly-funded broadcasterrsquos response to its concerns about the episode aired to mark Holocaust Memorial Day.Fans of Spurs, which has a prominent Jewish following, have branded the segment ldquodisgusting and called for the BBC to make a formal apology.The north London club has taken issue with footage in the episode that delved into allegations of racism against Spurs fans involving black Cha player Antonio Rudiger during a derby last year.Police and club investigations found no evidence to support the claims.After being contacted by PA, the BBC admitted it ldquodid not make sufficiently clear that no evidence of racism was found ndash and said it will edit the film, which is still available to view on its iPlayer, to reflect this.In a voice-over during the segment, BBC religion editor Martin Bashir tells viewers that some in society are continuing to use ldquofootball to express their racial hatred.During the programme, team vice-captain Harry Kane is shown making comments about how people ldquodid nothing to intervene in the Nazi genocide, as part of a video made by The National Holocaust Museum.The England strikerrsquos words are immediately followed by aerial shots of the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium and images from a clash between Spurs and Cha during which racial allegations were made against the home fans.Tensions flared at the top flight encounter on December  when play was halted after German defender Rudiger said he heard monkey noises coming from the home stands.Cha captain Cesar Azpilicueta discusses the events of the Spurs match during The One Show, saying: ldquoTo have this kind of discrimination is very sad.Owner of @ChaFCRoman Abramovich has commissioned a mural to mark #HolocaustMemorialDayand committed the club to challenge all forms of racial religious discrimination https:t.co rjxoSVvKMore on @BBCTheOneShowtonight @BBCOnepic BKQelsVbxmdash Martin BashirJanuary , The politan Police and Tottenham both conducted investigations, but they were closed on January  after finding ldquono evidence to corroborate or contradict the allegations of racial abuse.In its January newsletter, the Tottenham Hotspur Supportersrsquo Trusttold fans the clubrsquos lawyers were ldquocurrently in touch with the BBC.ldquoWe were contacted by a number of supporters following an item on BBC Onersquos The One Show on January , the trust wrote.ldquoWe raised the issue with Tottenham Hotspur FC, and the clubrsquos lawyers are currently in touch with the BBC.ldquoWhile those discussions are ongoing we cannot make any further comment, but will update when we can.Tottenham Hotspur said it would not be commenting on the ongoing discussions with the BBC when approached by PA.One Spurs fan claimed on Twitter that supporters had submitted official complaints to the BBC.Just seen on a unofficial Spurs Facebook group page that  of the group have made official complaints to the BBC over The One Show last night. I hope that the complaints are taken seriously.mdash Douglas BagleyJanuary , Another fan, season ticket holder Loraine Bergstrom, accused the BBC of ldquobias reporting and of ldquoportraying Spurs to be a racist club.She said the ldquomisrepresentation of Spurs was ldquodisgusting and called for the BBC to apologise.ldquoThe club was totally misrepresented during the whole report with cheap bad journalism by someone who hadnrsquot done any research, she told PA.ldquoSurely it would have been more beneficial to the report to have shown the England versus Bulgaria game where there was blatant racism.The One Show, watched daily by five million people, did not mention that Cha banned a fan for le after concluding they had racially abused Raheem Sterling at a home game in December .The episode, fronted by presenters Matt Baker and Alex Jones, also featured an interview with comedian David Baddiel about Holocaust deniers.The BBC said: ldquoWe do not accept that this short film implied that Spurs had in any way ignored racist behaviour.ldquoThe report concerned a mural commissioned by Cha Football Club and a video produced by the National Holocaust Museum to commemorate the th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz.ldquoHarry Kane was featured as part of the video alongside other footballers and no reasonable viewer would have drawn the conclusion that this was about Tottenhamrsquos response to the complaint of racist behaviour during the match between Spurs and Cha, or that Harry Kane was being critical of his Club or employers.ldquoHowever, we acknowledge that the use of images of the Spurs v Cha match did not make sufficiently clear to the viewer the subsequent outcome of the police and club investigation and we will edit this section of the film..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Tottenham complains to BBC over racism claims during The One Show

title: leader january 17 2020
story: Inspirational five-year-old Esmie MacLean who is fundraising to help her brother access expensive autism treatment can teach us all a lesson on altruism.While many children her age would be dreaming of what they want for their birthday # Esmie is six on Sunday # she has signed herself up to run m at this year#s MOK Run, which is no small feat for someone with such little legs.They say that early intervention can be the key to success, and other parents who have tried out the therapies for which Esmie is raising money, speak of outstanding results.It can be very hard to #go public# with such personal family matters, so not only should Esmie be commended, but also her mum and dad, Iona and Scott, who had the courage to talk out for the benefit of their family.Campbeltown always rallies when it comes to such worthwhile causes and every penny counts, so please donate whatever you can.We would like to wish Esmie the very best of luck for the race # and, of course, a very happy birthday on Sunday.

title: a louder voice for businesses in argyll
story: Mid Argyll Chamber of Commerce raised the prospect of a pan-Argyll business network at a special meeting in Lochgilphead, with business representatives invited from far and wide.The idea arose from meetings in  during which one of the subjects under discussion was the Rural Growth Deal, at which point it was realised there was no single business voice for Argyll.Businesspeople from Campbeltown, Oban and Lochgilphead attended the meeting, held on January  and hosted by MacLeod Construction, where chamber of commerce chairman David Smart said: #The intention is not to replicate the effort of organisations already in existence but to act as a hub or conduit for concerns.#The move was welcomed by Kintyre businessman Jim Martin, who stressed the impact on the area of recent job losses at CS Wind and Campbeltown Creamery.Mr Martin said: #It would be useful to be connected to other business groups around Argyll to give us more influence.#An important next step will be to look at the formation of a Kintyre business group to join the Oban and Dunoon Business Improvement Districts and Mid Argyll Chamber of Commerce in the umbrella organisation.It is hoped Helensburgh Chamber of Commerce will get involved and the need to include rural and island areas is high on the list.#Some of the benefits will be the potential for more clout with politicians at all levels and, hopefully, this will be a vehicle for bringing people together,# said David Smart.The move is supported by Argyll and Bute Council#s Business Gateway team and a follow-up meeting is planned.

title: joanna braves the shave in memory of dad
story: Last Saturday Joanna McMillan took part in Macmillan Cancer Support#s fundraising campaign in memory of her dad, E, who passed away from cancer exactly one year before, on January , .Brave the Shave sees people shave their head in support of men, women and children suffering from cancer. According Macmillan Cancer Support #brave shavers# have raised more than £. million since , which is enough to fund  Macmillan nurses for three years.Joanna, who sported shoulder- locks beforehand, was surrounded by family, friends, colleagues and well-wishers when hair stylist Kim Mathieson took the clippers to her head in the Fiddlers Bar on Saturday, leaving her with just a few millimetres of hair.Joanna, who lives in Campbeltown and works as a domestic at Kintyre Care Home, said: #I#ve wanted to do it for years as so many people get and are affected by cancer. After my dad died, I thought now is the time.#There are Macmillan nurses at Campbeltown Hospital and they do a lot for the people of the town.#Asked how she felt on the day Joanna said: #It was better than I thought it might be. I went into the pub about an hour before the shave and it was only in the last half hour that I started to get a bit nervous.#Joanna braved the shave just before there was a dip in the mercury, and when askedshe was managing to deal with the cold, she said: #We saw that there was snow forecast and a friend said to me that I#d chosen the wrong week, but I#ve got a nice warm hat so I#m fine # it#s just my neck that#s cold!#Joanna and her friends headed out and about after the shave and received many donations. She said: #The people of Campbeltown are brilliant # they are so generous. We raised a lot that night.#I#d like to thank everyone who has donated and also Kim who cut my hair.#So far Joanna has made more than £ # about £ in cash and a further £ on a JustGiving page set up by her friend # with more donations still to be added to the fund.Visit www.justgiving fundraising Joanna-Mcmillanyou would like to donate.
